title: Pursuing a flighty rabbit through dual space
text:
Part 1
I recently read this tweet by my friend, Ahmad Beirami. My education in concentration inequalities has been quite utilitarian, and Ahmad‚Äôs tweet confirmed to me that I am missing out on some deep geometric intuition in statistics. This has led me to revisit some primitives of statistics with which I have long had merely a pragmatic alliance ‚Äì among them the cumulant generating function, the Chernoff bound, and exponential families ‚Äì with the hope of forging a firmer friendship. This note represents these efforts.
Long term, my goal is to see how simple geometric properties of distribution space give rise to estimation theory, large-deviation theory, and online optimziation algorithms.
I don‚Äôt wish to get too bogged down in technical details. All the (in)equalities that follow hold under the mild assumption that they hold.


Exponential families
In their natural form, a parametric density p_\eta is an exponential family if it has the form p_\eta(x) = p(x) e^{\langle \eta, T(x)\rangle - A(\eta)}
Exponential families have many nice properties, including the following

1 \E_{p_\eta} [T(x)] = \nabla A |_\eta
2 \Cov_\eta(T(x)) = \nabla^2 A |_\eta
3 \E_\eta[e^{\lambda T(x)}] = A(\eta + \lambda) - A(\eta)
4 Given data x_1, ... x_n \sim p_\eta, the MLE for eta, \hat{\eta} is satisfies \nabla_\eta A(\hat\eta) = \sum_i T(x_i)/n
5 KL(p_\eta || p_\lambda) = D_A(\lambda || \eta) where D_A is the Bregman divergence under A.

These plain lemmas, which can be verified by simple computation, breed copiously amongst themselves to produce theorems that reveal the geometry that underlies so much of classical statistics. We‚Äôll scrutinize their progeny later.
For now, however, let us simply notice that, for any base (univariate) density p, we can define an exponential family by multiplying it by e^{\lambda x} and normalizing appropriately: p_\lambda(x) = e^{\lambda x}p(x)/E_p[e^{\lambda x}] = e^{\lambda x - \log \E [e^{\lambda X}]}p(x) so that A(\lambda) = \psi(\lambda) = \log \E [e^{\lambda X}] and \eta = \lambda. Thus, whenever we linearly tilt a density, the C.G.F. enters the stage merely as a normalizing constant. However, in its capacity as the log-partition function of the so-called Esscher transform , the C.G.F. acquires an interesting role in defining the geometry of \lambda-space
If P is a measure (as opposed to a density), we can define the tilted distribution through the Radon-Nikodym derivative \frac{dP_\lambda}{dP} = e^{\lambda x - \psi(\lambda)}. In this note, one can rest assured that essentially nothing is lost by considering this to be a somewhat ostentatious rewrite of the definitional statement p_\lambda(x)/p(x) = e^{\lambda x - \psi(\lambda)} .


The Chernoff Bound
Here is how the Chernoff argument typically runs in a Master‚Äôs class. We have an arbitrary random variable, X \sim P, and we wish to bound its tail probability, \Pr[X > t] \ ; \ t > \E_P[X]
The professor now pulls the following rabbit out of his or her hat: \mathrm{Pr}[X > t] = \inf_\lambda \mathrm{Pr}[e^{\lambda X} > e^{\lambda t}] \leq \inf_\lambda e^{- \lambda t + \log \E[e^{\lambda X}]]} = e^{-I(t)} 
Where I is the rate function (the Legendre dual of the CGF). Together, we then crank out pages of calculation to get supertight binomial tail bounds, or possibly characterize subgaussian or subexponential random variables. Meanwhile, the rabbit scampers away into a nearby shrub, never to reappear, and leaving me with ‚Äì at best ‚Äì a vague intuition that exponentiation pushes the random variable towards the tightest application of Markov‚Äôs inequality by making its distribution look more like two point-masses.
Like penitant students, let‚Äôs write this proof three more times and see whether the situation improves.

Proof 2: Inscriptions
As a starting point towards making this derivation look less miraculous, here‚Äôs one rewrite of the above standard proof, using the numerical inequality 1\{x > t\} \leq e^{\lambda(x - t)} for any \lambda > 0:
\Pr[X > t] = \E[1\{X > t}] \leq \inf_\lambda \E[e^{\lambda (X - t)}] \leq \inf_\lambda e^{\psi(\lambda) - \lambda t} = e^{-I(t)}
So exponentiating and applying Markov‚Äôs inequality is the same as inscribing the tail-indicators induced by X in an exponential, and then choosing their rates (\lambda) to optimize this surrogate on average over X.


Proof 3: Distributionspace
If numerical inequalities feel stringy to you, we can think of this in the space of distributions, equipped with the KL divergence. Recall that P is our law for X, and define E = \{X > t\}. Let‚Äôs also define Q = P(\cdot | E), because we then have KL(Q || P) = \log P(E) and thus for all \lambda > 0
0 \leq KL(Q || P_{\lambda}) = \E_Q [\log \frac{dQ}{dP}\frac {dP}{dP_{\lambda}}] = -\log P(E) - \lambda \E_Q[x] + \psi(\lambda) \leq -\log P(E) - \lambda t + \psi(\lambda)
since Q conditions on X > t.
So exponentiating and applying Markov‚Äôs inequality is the same as bounding e^{KL(P(\cdot | E) || P)} \leq e^{KL(Q || P_{\lambda}) + \E_P [\frac{dP_{\lambda}}{dP} | E]} \leq e^{\E_P [\frac{dP_{\lambda}}{dP} | E]} 
and then continuing along our previous argument e^{\E_P [\frac{dP_{\lambda}}{dP} | E]} \leq ...


Proof Âõõ: Tilting
Now, we will write the tail as an importance-weighted expectation under the distribution P_\lambda that satisfies \frac{dP_\lambda}{dP}(x) = e^{\lambda x - \log E[e^{\lambda X}]}. For any \lambda > 0, we have
\mathrm{Pr}[X > t] = \E[\mathbb{1}\{X > t\}] = \E_{P_\lambda}[\frac{dP}{dP_\lambda} \mathbb{1}\{X > t\}] \leq e^{- \lambda t + \psi(\lambda)}\Pr_{P_\lambda}[X > t]
We really have not done much here ‚Äì we‚Äôve just made the call to Markov‚Äôs inequality more explicit. But doing this reminds us that what we‚Äôre doing when we use Markov‚Äôs inequality is bounding the probability of the upper tail by 1. And so what we‚Äôre doing when we apply the Chernoff method is linearly tilting the base measure P according to some slope \lambda and bounding the tilted tail by 1. In doing this, we incur an additional term, e^{-\lambda t + \psi(\lambda)}, which is optimized by setting the derivative to zero: \psi'(\lambda^*) = t. By the properties of exponential families, this actually tells us that, at the optimal tilt, \lambda^* \E_{P_{\lambda^*}}[X] = \psi'(\lambda^*) = t That is, \lambda^* is the (unique) tilt that fixes the tilted mean to be t!
What is e^{-\lambda^* t + \psi(\lambda^*)} ? Well KL(P_{\lambda^*} || P) = \lambda \E_{P_{\lambda^*}}[X] - \psi(\lambda) = I(a)
This is a little better. The Chernoff bound is going to linearly tilt P until the tilted mean is t, and then pay for doing so with e^{-I(t)} = e^{-D(P_{\lambda^*} || P)}. So the more we have to linearly tilt P have the event t be unsurprising, the tighter our tail bound is.
Said another way, we take the MLE estimate for \lambda among the family of linear tilts of P under the observation x = t, and see how far it is from P in the Bregman geometry induced by the C.G.F potential (i.e.¬†in the Fisher-Information metric). This can be seen Properties 4 and 5 of Exponential Families above.

\Pr[X > t] = \E_{P_{\lambda^*}}[e^{\lambda X - \psi (\lambda)}\ind \{X > t\}]



Underlying Geometry
We just saw that the Chernoff bound can be written as \Pr[X > t] \leq e^{KL(P_{\lambda^*} || P)}, with \lambda^* chosen to make \E_{P_{\lambda^*}}[X] = t. In this part, we will prove that KL(P_{\lambda^*} || P) = \min_{Q \ : \ \E_Q[X] = t}KL(Q || P). This lets us write the Chernoff bound as
\Pr[X > t] \leq e^{-\min_{Q \ : \ \E_Q[X] = t}KL(Q || P)}
which has the pithy english translation: ‚Äúthe tail of X is controled by it `distance‚Äô to the set of measures with mean t as measured by KL.‚Äù Showing this is easy, since all we need to do is to show that P_{\lambda^*} is optimal on the RHS. But in doing so, we will underst
\inf_{Q \ : \ \E_Q[X] = t}KL(Q || P) is a dual formulation of \inf_{\lambda} \psi(\lambda) - \lambda t, where, as is common, the hard constraint leaps gracefully into the objective as a penalty.

Here is yet another view of the Chernoff bound. We can inscribe a step function in an exponential to get \Pr[X > t] = \E[1\{X > t\}] \leq \E[e^{\lambda (X - t)}] \leq e^{\psi(\lambda) - \lambda x}

The KL divergence, ever indifferent to the axions of distannces, fails to satisfy the triangle inequality.

title: A clean proof of Hoeffding‚Äôs inequality
text:
In the previous post, we made rather a meal out of proving the extremely simple fact that \Pr[X > t] \leq e^{- \sup_\lambda \lambda x - \psi(\lambda)}
where \psi(\lambda) = \log \E \exp{lambda X} is the CGF of X \sim P.
In this post, I‚Äôll try to make up for it by giving a quick and clean proof of Hoeffding‚Äôs inequality, based on the geometric properties established yesterday.
In upper bounding the CGF, Hoeffding‚Äôs inequality ‚Äì which states that for X \in [a, b] almost surely, \psi(\lambda) \leq \E_P[X] + (b - a)^2/4 ‚Äì allows us to lower bound the rate function, and therefore derive concrete concentration bounds. Let‚Äôs just prove this thing.
The key point is that, as the log-partition function of the Esscher family of P, \psi(\lambda) satisfies the following properties

1 \psi'(\lambda) = \E_{P_{\lambda}}[X]
2 \psi''(\lambda) = \Var_{P_{\lambda}}[X].

Taylor expanding \psi around 0 gives
\psi(\lambda) = \psi(0) + \psi'(0) + \psi''(\zeta)/2 \ \ \ \zeta \in [0, \lambda]
so that
\psi(\lambda) = \E_P[X] + \Var_{P_{\lambda}}[X]
The RV whose law is P^{\lambda} is still bounded within [a, b], so we have the uniform bound on its variance (b - a)^2/2 (worst case variance is equal pointmasses on each of a and b). So
\psi(\lambda) = \E_P[X] + \frac{(b - a)^2}{4}
So the Esscher family being an exponential family made our life super easy. More sophisticated concentration inequalities, like Bernstein and Bennet, have exactly the same template, but we exert finer control over the second moment.
